title: Vote for Women tag
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032im_/http:/typophile.com/files/n9066br_3942.jpg)
  
Have discovered it was used on a banner in 1920.
author: Sam Lowry

comments.content: Might be hand drawn -- the /O aren't identical.

No digital equivalent for this variation of Concave Tuscan. Many but not all had spurs. For example:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CondensedConcavePhillipsOFTB_4435.jpg)
  
almost none are are digitized. Not really close, but part of the concave family  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ConcaveExtendeAsVotes_5100.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/concave-extended/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/concave-extended/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/concave-extended/")  
Don

1920 on fabric. Perhaps printed with wood-block letters.  
Might be worth checking Hamilton/Page.  
Don
Though obviously not the same, it is certainly similar to Adobe's Juniper (if one was looking for a similar modern representation).

EDITED:  
Yes, Juniper is a descendant of the concave family. As close as any of the digital fonts mentioned so far. Link [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/juniper/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/juniper/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/juniper/")  
Don

[Arched Gothic Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/arched-gothic-condensed-sg) Sg might work pretty well as digital alternative. There's also [Show](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417161032/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/juan-jose-lopez/show) but you'd have to fill all perforations contrasting and condensing it more.

Arched Gothic Condensed SG a direct descendant of the 19th century concave that was the basis these letters. For people who like to tinker with fonts to make a match, it's the best candidate so far.  
Don
